5. This ignorance is required, to be more precise, in the three leading flexible-price equilibrium models, namely, those of Lucas (1972a), Lucas (1973), and Barro (1981, pp. 42-50). It is possible that other such models do not have this property.

6. The relevant point was mentioned by Barro (1981) and was very recently emphasized by Grossman (1982). Grossman recognizes, but does not accept, the possibility that money-output correlations are due to reserve causation, i.e., monetary responses to output movements generated by shocks to technology or preferences, as suggested by King and Plosser (1982).
